segments.text: The board meetings in those days were held in the old... Boardroom.
Boardroom.
Yeah, which was a board, a board, yeah, was a wood building.
That old Victorian house north of Sabeasa.
Yeah, it was near the dining hall there, in that area, yeah, and down the, well, you know where it was.
In the era before open meetings, by law, normally who from Texas A&M, as in terms of people employed by A&M, who normally went to the board meetings?
Only who Mr. Rutter invited and approved, to put it that simply.
He usually invited me to go because he had a lot of things he had asked me to develop and he didn't know thoroughly the background.
But I would sit in the corner.
I wouldn't say a word until he invited me to say something in the early days.
And of course there were no reporters there.
No faculty, no students, unless invited.
No, the only female was usually the secretary taking notes, recording the minutes.
Normally how long did board meetings last?
The usual pattern was that they would come in the night before and would be housed on campus and usually have a dinner.
Well, often Mr.
Rudder would feed some drinking place for them off campus, usually the country club.
And they would meet all, start, have breakfast early, start very early, in modern standards, about eight o'clock, definitely on their way.
And it would go usually all day, and sometimes it would last two days.
But usually it was a full day meeting.
They would usually get through late, fairly late at night, 6.30 or so.
Now in the 60s, the board members came and went by plane,
They weren't coming by train, were they?
It varied with the person that would drive or be driven by a chauffeur that would come here, and some would come by plane.
But as I recall, not too many, well, until the university got its own airplane.
They used to fly some of the board members in.
Now that would be taboo, I guess, knowing it.
Let's see, kind of a trivia question.
Given the state laws at the time, were alcoholic beverages ever served on campus for board events in that era?
Not to my knowledge, Haskell.
Because to my knowledge, it was always off campus.
Oh, yeah.
If there was any alcoholic beverage at all.
In fact, well, I guess you probably know this.
We used to hide where the money came from to buy the alcohol, the source of what we were buying, really.
Well, I wouldn't hide it, but the person asked to do it would, was not to disclose where the money came from or what it was for.
Right.

Now, when I became dean of faculties, Buck Wirus called me over that day and said, here is a $500 account at the former student association, and if you need to spend any money on anything for which you're not supposed to spend state money, charge it to this account.
give us a receipt, and never, never, never, even if it's a glass of wine, never charge that to the state account.
Charge that to the student account.
Right.
And that happened even before that, when Dick Hervey was the
headed the Former Students Association.
He used to give Earl about five times what he would allocate to me, but he would allocate a sum to me.
And we were told the same story.
And to buy things that we were not supposed to use state money for.
There were many things we weren't.
Now when the board members came for a meeting here, they normally did not bring their wives?
Not many did, to my knowledge.
Because many of them stayed right on the campus.
And was Mrs. Cashin still living there, taking care of the house, Red Cashin's mother?
She was initially, yeah.
because I knew that I've heard many of them say very positive things about her thoughtfulness.
Yeah.
Let's see.
Mr. Rutter, during the 60s, Dr. Harrington was the chancellor.
And how did things flow?
On what basis did things go from President Rutter to Chancellor Harrington?
Did all matters go to the board through the chancellor?
Well, initially before Earl came to be appointed as president, first he was appointed academic, I mean appointed vice president without portfolio.
And then he was, they all knew he was going to be present, so it was announced shortly.
At that time, Dr. Harrington was both chancellor and president of A&M College and chancellor of the system.
So after Mr. Rutter came, there was initially a little jostling, I guess you'd put it politely, of who had the call on what.
But Mr. Rutter initially was more than willing to bend over backwards to try to get along with Tom and to coordinate things for Tom.
And they were fairly compatible.
I've seen others, chancellors and presidents that weren't, but they were.

Anything about A&M University and later, when after Mr. Murutter took over the services, the Extension Service and Experiment Station and the Engineering Extension Service and Experiment Station and Transportation Institute, he was very zealous that he had the input of what was going to happen in those units.
Initially, it was only A&M College.
But as president, he wanted the services and the stations to report through the president.
In fact, he brought that about.
That's what I had heard.
Oh, yes.

Some of the board members, just to be frank, I shouldn't sometimes be candid as I am, but some of the board members at the time thought that Chancellor Tom Harrington was not active enough or aggressive enough in pushing things for A&M.
And they more or less challenged Mr. Rutter to do that and eventually gave him the responsibility for doing it.
All right.
If you could organize  in this question, I give you imperial power.
How would you organize the structure for the stations and the services?
Where would they report?
I think they should be under the campus university in which they're housed.
I'm not a strong believer in a strong system arrangement.
In fact, I'm not a strong believer in a large system continually taking in new institutions.
It only dilutes the resources.
I can't imagine today that it helps Texas A&M at all to have these others except perhaps for Prairie View as members of the same organizational unit.
First of all, they're quite different.
Most of those others are primarily teaching institutions.
But Haskell, in the early days, Prairie View thought that they were blood brothers to A&M.
Oh, no, I agree.
To mostly the agriculture relationships, and they weren't.
I agree.
Very close relationships were had.
That one I understand.
Let's see, the Tarleton, I mean, excuse me, the Arlington giveaway, that occurred after you left?
Yes.
No, no, no.
That happens during Rutter's regime and when I was here.
Can you review that, please?
Well, I frankly don't know all of the details, but there was disagreements between Mr. Rutter and some of the people there responsible.
It wasn't Wendell.
No, no.
It wasn't he, because he and Mr. Rutter got along well.
It was people on the different boards, I think, were primarily fighting.
I'm not fully privy of all what happened, but all I know is
I agreed with Mr.
Rudder that it was a blessing to get rid of Arlington.
They gave it to the University of Texas.
They wanted it.
And we got the Galveston campus about the same time.
How did that come about, the Galveston?
Well, primarily through the Moody
family and foundation and strong former students in this area backing it.
And I guess Babe Swartz probably helped.
Yes.
That's one way we got Babe Swartz's approval on other things by backing what he wanted in the Galveston area.
And you want to know how it came about?
Well, it was 100 acres donated to start with on Pelican Island for it.
which one of the former students, a large multimillionaire still, and the Moody family helped put up the money.
Mary Moody, Mary Northern Moody, was a very strong proponent of Mr.
Rudder.
She liked him immensely.
She liked the military.
Their dad was a military person.
And she was difficult to get along with, but she really liked Mr.
Rudder and what he was doing.
Now, I've heard a 99th-hand report that one of the old forts, Coast Artillery Forts, in the middle of the seawall, that property was also offered to A&M.
Do you remember anything?
Yeah, I believe so.
And I can't recall offhand exactly the reasons that they didn't follow through on it.
There was a reason.
You want to know also why Galveston was coveted and wanted.
Oceanography was being built up very strong.
probably had more impetus than any other unit in A&M at the time.
And they wanted an outlet to the sea, naturally.
Sure.

And that's one reason we started with the biological laboratory there, Marine Biology Laboratory, which became then the cadets, I mean the maritime people and all that, and the actual campus being established.
I was on the board of visitors when they started.
Yeah, I was there for three years before I left A&M.
All right.
Now, they're going to be celebrating their 50th anniversary very soon because John Calhoun mentioned that to me the other day.
I don't know whether it's this fall or not, the creation of the oceanography program here.
It's hard to realize it's been going that long.
Yeah.
changes, the modifications were making headway.
Do you remember any events that where he thought, okay, we're making progress?
Well, Mr. Rutter was not a talkative or a euphoric person.
He confided in few people about his feelings about anything.
But, uh,
Sounds like I'm bragging, but I think I was closer to him.
He confided more in me than he did in anybody else on the campus, including his own wife, which I shouldn't say.
She would confirm.
She'd tell you the same thing.
You bet.
I had a good interview with her the other day, and she was saying that she didn't know much of anything that happened at the office.
Oh, well, her kids will tell you they didn't.
Mr. Rutter never brought anything home.
We never discussed university business.
All right, so he shared some things with you.
Who else did he share feelings, frustrations, joys with?
Do you know?
Yeah, in some things with Tiger Teague, because they were pretty close.
They were cut from the same cloth, too.
Tiger was just as aggressive as Earl Rudder was, and very capable, and they respected each other.
Yeah, and Maggie McGee is probably one other that I recall that he would confide some in.
But he knew these people would never mention it.
was never in any danger of anything he told Tiger or Maggie.
They're the two that are outside the university that I think he probably confided in the most.
Do you remember any examples of Washington help where Mr. Teague's role was very, very significant?
Oh, yeah.
There's probably dozens of examples, Haskell.
You can name three or four or five of the major buildings on the campus that came from Tiger Teague's intercession, along with the other politicians, of course, LBJ being president and so forth.
I know in the 70s, Mr. Teague got a rider on the Veterans Appropriation Bill to link medical schools with VA hospitals.
And he was also very helpful in us acquiring what used to be called Bryan Air Force Base.
Oh, I hadn't thought of that, yes.
Yeah, well, there was a lot of entanglement that had to be unraveled at the federal level, and it wasn't just the state matters taking it over.
It had to be settled at the federal level, and Tiger carried that ball.
And he carried the ball on anything Earl Rutter asked him to do, he would follow through.
Do you remember anything that Mr. Teague turned down, whether it came about or not?
No, I can't write.
directly say that.
I know, like Earl, initially he was opposed to coeducation and dropping or deemphasizing military.
He thought we were deemphasizing it.
On the racial integration, I've never heard any negative.
Do you remember anybody being contrary to that?
To being integrated?
No.
As surprising as it might sound to outsiders, not to you and I, people were more opposed to coeducation and women and dropping the emphasis on military, and they were on accepting the blacks.
In fact, I remember
board members that I attended in the early days saying, We've got to bring the blacks in.
They're the great football players.
A&M's going to be great.
And oh, Paul Bear Bryant used to emphasize that to Mr. Ruddard.
I can remember what Mr. Ruddard turned to him.
He said, Mr. Bryant, girls don't play football.
He says, yes, but I'm going to get a lot of good players here because they can come here.
I remember hearing Mr. Heaton speak negatively about integration, but as I understand it, Mr.
Rudder told Mr. Heaton to review all the transcripts.

those first armed military personnel now did is it correct that mr. Rutter contacted the Pentagon and said send some black armed services members when you send this year's group to begin summer school include some black
He probably did, knowing Mr.
Rudder, but I can't vouch for that Haskell, because he handled that type of matter.
He and Dean Hannigan handled most of that.
I wasn't involved directly in that type of thing.
He knew that I was
favored not only co-education, but integration, too.
Integration came about much easier than most of these other things.
Of course, people may not say that now, but it did.
Do you remember any proposals that Mr. Rutter came forth that at first you were hesitant about, but he persuaded you to change your mind?
No, I can't, because most of my involvement was in the academic research area.
And I cannot honestly say that he ever turned down anything that I thought we should be doing in those areas.
In the other areas of leadership and administration,
It was not his normal tendency to consult other people about this.
He did it, and then you were told about it.
That's what I understood.
And I'm assuming that on research, he didn't claim to be highly knowledgeable.
Oh, no, no.
Margaret will tell you this herself, but he never made any claim to be even an academic.
She used to say how he used to tell her how fortunate he was to get some good academic people to run the place for him.
Because I know we faculty members, when he would speak, say, to the arts and sciences faculty, we never accused him of trying to pose as an academic or anything like that.
No, you know, he got an honorary doctorate from Baylor.
I remember that.
Yeah, but he never used it or never insisted on anybody calling him.
I never remember anything about Dr. Earl Rudder after that.
I used to tell him kind of in jest, I said, don't make any play out of that doctorate, because most doctor degrees don't mean a pinch of shit.
That's right.
All right.
Do you remember any humorous incidents where something just went wrong, something fizzled out, something
Yeah, there's a couple of anecdotes.
I'm going to tell you one.
There was a former student who was on the faculty
He was caught out on what was then the old Aggie Experiment Station building, making out with one of the secretaries.
And he was hauled in to Mr. Rutter for chastisement and discipline.
And Mr. Rutter, I wasn't present, but he told me immediately afterward, was laughing as much as I'd ever heard him laugh.
He said, I called that guy in, and I said, damn it, X.
He said, as a former student, I thought you would have more sense, if you're going to do this, to get off the campus.
And he says, if I ever catch you doing it again, I'll kick your ass all the way to Austin.
What were Mr.
Rudder's real dislikes?
Was there something that those of you who worked with him closely knew not to do?
Well, as I've said in this account that I wrote up, there was two things that I learned early and I was not to press or to discuss too much with Mr. Reuter.
First was what he ate or wanted to eat, and second half what his health was.
These were taboo areas as far as I was concerned.
There were other things too.
He had a good sense of humor.
Oh yeah, he had a sense of humor.
What time did his work day normally begin?
What time did he get to the office?
In the early days, he would get there quite early, often before 8 o'clock, maybe 7.30, but towards the last of his tenure, it slipped more and more.
I think it was the way he was feeling mostly.
In the early days, he came back after supper?
Oh, we never went home until we got the job done.
We stayed there until it was 9.30 at night.
Oh, in the early days, Dorsey and I would collect in his office every night as a ritual.
It wasn't a daytime activity, it was a nighttime activity, and we would discuss all the plans and things that he had encountered during the day and he wanted solutions to, and on and on.
Let's see, Dean Hannigan was appointed dean of students while you were in the administration, wasn't he?
Yeah.
Oh, I don't recall exactly, but it was in the second or third year after I was appointed by Mr. Rutter.
Now, how did Mr. Rutter identify him?
He brought him in on his own.
As you know, he was a former military officer.
Did he know him?
He had known him.
I guess he didn't work with him, but he had known him through some contacts, and it was highly recommended by others.
No, I had nothing to do with bringing Dean Hannigan here.
That was strictly Mr. Rutter and his own input through the military circle.
In your own work, when you went over to become an administrator, your laboratory work ceased.
Is that right?
Or did you continue?
Essentially, I was made chairman of the department.
before I was in higher administration in the School of Agriculture to run the Department of Plant Physiology and Pathology, which later became called Plant Sciences.
During that tenure, one of the first things, Mr. Rutter had just come in in 1958.
It was through his intercession that we got the Plant Science building.
Askey told him what I wanted done was a new plant science building, and it came about, even though he wasn't officially the president at that time.
Even though I had an office and a laboratory in the plant science building, I never used it much except to meet with the graduate students that I was finishing up.
I soon learned that you couldn't wear three hats.
You couldn't be a good administrator and be a good faculty member, too, even though Mr. Rutter kept telling me that I could do all of that stuff.
In fact, that's the way he convinced me to go into administration, saying, oh, you can still do research.
You can still teach.
Oh, yeah, just like administration was a side issue, like hell it was.
Now, in your teaching days, how many doctoral students did you direct?
Do you remember?
I don't remember exactly, but both master's degree and doctorate, they were well over 60, between 60 and 75.
I think the doctorates were about 23, as I recall.
I could look it up if you need to know.
The research that you did on cotton, you started that after you got down here?
Oh, yeah, I'd never seen it.
Well, I'd seen a cotton plant in the greenhouse, but I didn't know anything about cotton, no.
I was from the Middle West.
That's what I thought.
It was corn or wheat or cattle, yeah, sure.
All right, now, what was your primary crop, research crop in Kentucky?
Well, the Little Eye tobacco was the main research crop there at the university and on the experiment station.
But I wasn't there long enough to really get involved.
I did some minor research and consultation on the tobacco, but I was working mostly on the origin of ethylene in plants.
And if anything that was associated, I thought, well, that I would work with.
I was employed internally as a teacher.
I didn't have any research appointment in Kentucky.
I did research, but I didn't have any appointment.
When you got down here, how long did it take you to jump into the cotton?
One year.
When I came,
Dr. Lewis, R.D.
Lewis, director of the Ag Experiment Station.
In my initial meeting with him, I promised he would get me a 25% appointment.
I asked him for it the first year, and he said he couldn't bring it about because things were tough, hard up at that time.
But the second year, he came through on his agreement.
Describe Dr. Lewis and his role at Texas A&M.
Well, Dr. Lewis, like many of the early A&M leaders, was a no-nonsense man.
He was strictly business, but that doesn't mean that he was mechanical or anything like that.
He was a caring person too, but he expected you to do your job and to do it right.
And if you didn't, then you caught hell from him.
He and I got along quite well because
Well, one reason, his son was in my class that I taught in the first year I was here, and his son went home and told his dad, Wayne Hall's a hell of a good teacher.
That's what he told me later.
Very good.
Now, he had not, Lewis had not, he's not a native Texan.
No, he came here from Ohio, and I believe he was from Ohio originally, or maybe it was Missouri.
It was one of the Midwest states.
I don't know, but I think it was the Midwest.
And I remember on the Aspirations Committee, he seemed to me to have clear foresight.
he could see a broad horizon.
Can I take a brief?
Missed opportunities.
Well, to start with Haskell, I've never been one to moan missed opportunities in my past.
I know there's things that
escape me and didn't turn out right and probably should have been done differently, but I'm not one to.
But are there any that A&M missed?
Any doors that were open that we didn't realize it and now we realize they were?
I think we could have brought about some of the things faster than we accomplished.
But it's a matter of building.
And as you know, universities are not built up, even though they are built up and their reputation lags their real estate.
Do you remember any great scholars that we almost got?
Oh, yeah, there's dozens of those in those early days.
One thing Mr. Rutter gave me as an assignment was to bring in some outstanding faculty, and he was willing to see that we provided he and the board members money.
For a reasonable number, not a limited course.
Oh, yeah, I remember going with Andy Suttle, for example, out on the West Coast, and we met with five different Nobel laureates.
We were trying to entice coming in a couple that Andy had known at the University of Chicago, namely Dr. Libby, who was his mentor, and the famous chemist.
His name slips me right now, but anyway.
We almost got one or two of them to come here, but we missed out.
You were asking about disappointments.
That was one of my... What more could we have done in hindsight to have...

I don't think because at that time A&M's reputation, even though we liked to pat ourselves on the back and say we were always great, at that time it really wasn't attractive to a lot of people unless they could see really a challenge to do something.

The reason I was able to entice Dean Zehner and Dean Horace Byers to come here was to convince them that they'd done about all they could do at their present institutions, were well recognized, but here they could do something that couldn't be done elsewhere.
That's one reason.
But that story didn't carry with the Nobel laureates in the earlier days.
Who identified chemistry and economics to get special emphasis?
I think that, well, I hesitate to say that I did it alone, but I was the impetus for Flint.
Mr. Rutter gave me almost unlimited authority to establish priorities and do things in the academic area and the research area within reason.
Of course, I was always consulting with him before final approval.
I remember talking to Mel Greenhut after
years later.
I talked Mel Greenhut into coming here, yeah.
Did you?
Sure did.
Now how did you identify him?
Through the department chairman of Grice, who you might have known.
Did you?
Don't recall his name.
I was trying to recall his name.
He came here, and Mel tried to get him to come here later.
Oh, okay.
But the real thing, besides getting Mel as chairman, was getting the Michigan State group as a team to come.
We got four of them to come at once.
Literally looted their department there.
We paid, supposedly in those days, pretty good salaries.
Now, and that...
